title: Why doesn't 'how come' require 'do'or 'does'? - Quora
tags: United Nations Security Council Veto Power

response.answer_text: I suspect you are asking because you see “how come” as a synonym for “why” and since “why” is usually followed by a form of ‘to do’ it puzzles you that ‘how come’ does not. But many of our language rules don’t depend on the meaning of a word or phrase, but on its form. I don’t know the official derivation of the phrase ‘how come,’ but I suspect it is a contraction of “How does it come about that…” So instead of saying “How does it come about that drivers ignore yellow lights?” we say “How come drivers ignore yellow lights?” The word ‘how’ is an adverb, so we need to supply the verb it modifies—usually a form of ‘to do’ when we are asking a question. But when we begin the sentence with ‘how come’ the verb is ‘come’ and the adverb is ‘how’ so the verb and its modifier are already there. I’m sure a linguistics expert would have a more erudite explanation.
